items.text: I tend to give people the benefit of the doubt, even when they've let me down before.
items.rationale: Willingness to forgive and extend trust reflects the forgivingness and gentleness facets of HEXACO Agreeableness.

items.text: When someone criticizes me, I can usually stay calm and not take it personally.
items.rationale: Emotional even-temperedness in the face of provocation is a core marker of HEXACO Agreeableness (patience facet).

items.text: I rarely hold grudges, even against people who have treated me badly.
items.rationale: Forgivingness is a defining facet of HEXACO Agreeableness.

items.text: People describe me as easygoing and hard to anger.
items.rationale: Low anger reactivity and patience are central to HEXACO Agreeableness.

items.text: I'm willing to compromise in an argument rather than insist on having my way.
items.rationale: Flexibility and willingness to yield in conflicts reflects the gentleness and patience facets of Agreeableness.

items.text: I try not to be too judgmental of others, even when I disagree with their choices.
items.rationale: Tolerance and non-judgmental attitudes are hallmarks of high Agreeableness.

items.text: Even when I'm frustrated with someone, I make an effort to be gentle in how I express it.
items.rationale: Gentleness facet of HEXACO Agreeableness involves being mild-mannered in interpersonal dealings.

items.text: I can tolerate a lot of annoying behavior from others before I lose my temper.
items.rationale: High frustration tolerance maps directly to the patience facet of Agreeableness.

items.text: When people are rude to me, I usually just let it go rather than confront them.
items.rationale: Avoidance of confrontation and willingness to overlook slights reflects high Agreeableness.

items.text: I find it easy to forgive someone who has sincerely apologized.
items.rationale: Readiness to forgive is a core component of the forgivingness facet.

items.text: Others would say I'm one of the most patient people they know.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of patience directly taps the patience facet of Agreeableness.

items.text: I prefer cooperation over competition in most situations.
items.rationale: Preference for cooperation over competition reflects the cooperative, non-antagonistic nature of Agreeableness.

items.text: I sometimes go along with what others want just to keep the peace, even when I shouldn't.
items.rationale: While this reflects high agreeableness through conflict avoidance, it could also suggest low assertiveness, which in HEXACO falls under Extraversion.

items.text: I tend to see the good in people, which sometimes means I get taken advantage of.
items.rationale: Seeing the good in people is agreeable, but being taken advantage of could also relate to low Honesty-Humility awareness or naivety.

items.text: I find it hard to say no to people, even when their requests are unreasonable.
items.rationale: Difficulty refusing others could reflect high Agreeableness (flexibility, gentleness) but also low social boldness, a facet of Extraversion in HEXACO.

items.text: I always double-check my work before submitting it.
items.rationale: Thoroughness and attention to detail are core markers of the perfectionism facet of Conscientiousness.

items.text: I keep a detailed schedule and rarely miss a deadline.
items.rationale: Organization and time management are central to the organization facet of Conscientiousness.

items.text: My workspace is always neat and well-organized.
items.rationale: Physical orderliness is a direct behavioral indicator of the organization facet.

items.text: I set long-term goals and work steadily toward them, even when progress is slow.
items.rationale: Goal persistence and diligence are hallmarks of the diligence facet of Conscientiousness.

items.text: When I start a task, I don't stop until it's completed to my satisfaction.
items.rationale: Task persistence and high standards reflect both diligence and perfectionism facets.

items.text: People know they can count on me to follow through on my commitments.
items.rationale: Reliability and dependability are core behavioral expressions of Conscientiousness.

items.text: I think carefully before making decisions, weighing all the pros and cons.
items.rationale: Deliberation and careful decision-making reflect the prudence facet of Conscientiousness.

items.text: I make lists for almost everything—groceries, tasks, even things I want to talk about.
items.rationale: List-making is a concrete behavioral indicator of the organization facet.

items.text: I avoid impulsive decisions and prefer to plan things out in advance.
items.rationale: Impulse control and planning map to the prudence facet of Conscientiousness.

items.text: I take my responsibilities very seriously, sometimes more seriously than others think is necessary.
items.rationale: Strong sense of duty and responsibility is a defining feature of Conscientiousness.

items.text: Even for small tasks, I like to do them properly rather than cut corners.
items.rationale: Perfectionism and thoroughness even in minor tasks is a clear Conscientiousness marker.

items.text: I rarely act on a whim—I like to think things through first.
items.rationale: Low impulsivity and deliberation are central to the prudence facet.

items.text: I sometimes spend so much time perfecting details that I miss the bigger picture.
items.rationale: While perfectionism is a Conscientiousness facet, excessive detail focus could also relate to anxiety-driven behavior (Emotionality).

items.text: I feel uneasy when things around me are messy or disorganized, even if they aren't mine.
items.rationale: Discomfort with disorder maps to organization, but the emotional discomfort component could partially reflect Emotionality.

items.text: I get anxious when I haven't prepared thoroughly for an upcoming event or meeting.
items.rationale: Preparation maps to Conscientiousness, but the anxiety response is a core feature of Emotionality (anxiety facet).

items.text: I worry a lot about things that might go wrong, even when everything seems fine.
items.rationale: Chronic worry and anticipatory anxiety are core markers of the anxiety facet of HEXACO Emotionality.

items.text: I feel a strong emotional bond with the people close to me and would be devastated to lose them.
items.rationale: Deep attachment and fear of loss reflect the dependence and sentimentality facets of Emotionality.

items.text: I sometimes cry during movies or when hearing a particularly moving story.
items.rationale: Emotional reactivity to sentimental stimuli is a hallmark of the sentimentality facet.

items.text: I need a lot of emotional support from others when I'm going through a difficult time.
items.rationale: Need for emotional support and reassurance maps directly to the dependence facet of Emotionality.

items.text: I tend to panic in stressful situations rather than staying calm.
items.rationale: Panic responses under stress reflect the anxiety and fearfulness facets of Emotionality.

items.text: Physical dangers frighten me more than they seem to frighten most people.
items.rationale: Heightened fear of physical harm is a direct indicator of the fearfulness facet.

items.text: I often feel anxious about my health, even when there's no real reason to be concerned.
items.rationale: Health anxiety reflects the broader anxiety facet of Emotionality.

items.text: When someone I care about is upset, I feel their pain almost as if it were my own.
items.rationale: Empathic distress and emotional contagion are markers of the sentimentality facet.

items.text: I would feel very uncomfortable being alone in a dangerous neighborhood at night.
items.rationale: Situational fear and avoidance of physical danger map to the fearfulness facet.

items.text: I find it hard to cope with stressful situations without leaning on someone for support.
items.rationale: Reliance on others during stress is a core expression of the dependence facet.

items.text: Small setbacks can ruin my entire day because I can't stop thinking about them.
items.rationale: Rumination and emotional vulnerability to minor stressors reflect high Emotionality.

items.text: I get very attached to personal possessions that have sentimental value.
items.rationale: Sentimental attachment to objects reflects the sentimentality facet of Emotionality.

items.text: I feel deeply moved when I see acts of kindness between strangers.
items.rationale: Being moved by kindness reflects sentimentality, but could also relate to Agreeableness (tender-mindedness) or Honesty-Humility (sincerity).

items.text: I tend to overthink social interactions and worry about whether I said the wrong thing.
items.rationale: Social rumination reflects anxiety, but the social-evaluative component could also relate to low social boldness (Extraversion).

items.text: I feel nervous and self-conscious when I have to speak in front of a group.
items.rationale: Performance anxiety involves fearfulness (Emotionality) but also low social boldness, which is a facet of Extraversion in HEXACO.

items.text: I love being the center of attention at social gatherings.
items.rationale: Enjoyment of social attention is a direct marker of the social boldness facet of Extraversion.

items.text: I feel energized after spending time with a large group of people.
items.rationale: Social energy gain is a classic indicator of the sociability facet of Extraversion.

items.text: I'm usually the one who starts conversations with strangers.
items.rationale: Initiating social contact with unfamiliar people reflects social boldness.

items.text: Most days, I wake up feeling cheerful and optimistic about what lies ahead.
items.rationale: Dispositional positive affect and optimism are core markers of the liveliness facet of Extraversion.

items.text: I feel confident taking charge in group situations, even with people I don't know well.
items.rationale: Leadership confidence with unfamiliar others reflects social boldness and social self-esteem.

items.text: I have a wide circle of friends and acquaintances.
items.rationale: Maintaining a large social network is a behavioral indicator of the sociability facet.

items.text: People often describe me as lively and full of energy.
items.rationale: Third-person descriptions of vitality and energy map to the liveliness facet.

items.text: I enjoy parties and large social events much more than quiet evenings at home.
items.rationale: Preference for large social gatherings over solitude is a defining feature of sociability.

items.text: I rarely feel shy or awkward in new social situations.
items.rationale: Low social anxiety and comfort in novel social settings reflect social boldness.

items.text: I tend to laugh a lot and find humor in everyday situations.
items.rationale: Frequent laughter and humor appreciation reflect the liveliness and positive emotionality of Extraversion.

items.text: I feel very comfortable expressing my opinions in a group, even if they're unpopular.
items.rationale: Willingness to voice opinions publicly reflects social boldness and confidence.

items.text: I generally feel good about myself and my abilities.
items.rationale: Positive self-regard maps to the social self-esteem facet of HEXACO Extraversion.

items.text: I enjoy meeting new people and find it easy to make a good first impression.
items.rationale: While sociability is clear, making a good impression could also involve social awareness related to Agreeableness.

items.text: I like to keep busy and always have something going on in my life.
items.rationale: High activity level relates to Extraversion's liveliness, but could also reflect the diligence facet of Conscientiousness.

items.text: I naturally take the lead on group projects because I like making sure things get done right.
items.rationale: Taking the lead reflects social boldness (Extraversion), but the motivation of doing things right suggests Conscientiousness (diligence/perfectionism).

items.text: I would never accept a bribe, no matter how large the amount.
items.rationale: Refusal of corrupt incentives is a direct marker of the fairness facet of Honesty-Humility.

items.text: I don't think I'm more important or special than anyone else.
items.rationale: Absence of entitlement and superiority beliefs reflects the modesty facet.

items.text: I have no interest in owning expensive luxury items just to impress others.
items.rationale: Low materialism and disinterest in status symbols map to the greed avoidance facet.

items.text: I would rather be honest and face the consequences than lie to get out of trouble.
items.rationale: Valuing honesty over self-protection reflects the sincerity facet.

items.text: I don't use flattery or manipulation to get what I want from people.
items.rationale: Avoidance of manipulative social tactics is a core marker of the sincerity facet.

items.text: I believe that everyone deserves to be treated fairly, regardless of their status.
items.rationale: Commitment to fairness and equity reflects the fairness facet of Honesty-Humility.

items.text: I don't feel entitled to special treatment, even when I've accomplished something noteworthy.
items.rationale: Absence of entitlement after achievement is a clear indicator of the modesty facet.

items.text: Accumulating wealth has never been a major priority in my life.
items.rationale: Low emphasis on wealth accumulation maps directly to the greed avoidance facet.

items.text: I am straightforward in my dealings with others and don't pretend to be something I'm not.
items.rationale: Authenticity and lack of pretense are hallmarks of the sincerity facet.

items.text: I would feel terrible about cheating on a test, even if I knew I wouldn't get caught.
items.rationale: Internalized moral standards against dishonesty, independent of detection, reflect the fairness facet.

items.text: I don't need others to admire me or look up to me.
items.rationale: Low need for admiration reflects the modesty facet of Honesty-Humility.

items.text: If a cashier gave me too much change, I would return the extra money.
items.rationale: Honest behavior in low-stakes financial situations is a behavioral marker of the fairness facet.

items.text: I try to be genuine in my interactions, even when it would be easier to just tell people what they want to hear.
items.rationale: Genuineness maps to sincerity, but telling people what they want to hear also relates to Agreeableness (people-pleasing).

items.text: I don't like to brag about my achievements, even when I'm proud of them.
items.rationale: Avoidance of bragging reflects modesty, but could also relate to low social boldness (Extraversion) or social norms.

items.text: I tend to downplay my successes because I don't want others to feel bad about themselves.
items.rationale: Downplaying success reflects modesty (Honesty-Humility), but the motivation of protecting others' feelings maps to Agreeableness (gentleness).

items.text: I love exploring philosophical questions about the nature of reality and existence.
items.rationale: Engagement with abstract philosophical inquiry is a core marker of the inquisitiveness facet.

items.text: I am deeply moved by art, music, and literature in ways that are hard to put into words.
items.rationale: Aesthetic sensitivity and deep emotional responses to art reflect the aesthetic appreciation facet.

items.text: I enjoy thinking about unconventional ideas that challenge mainstream thinking.
items.rationale: Attraction to unconventional ideas reflects the unconventionality facet of Openness.

items.text: I have a vivid imagination and often daydream about fantastical scenarios.
items.rationale: Vivid imagination and fantasy proneness are direct indicators of the creativity facet.

items.text: I find beauty in things that most people would overlook or consider ordinary.
items.rationale: Heightened aesthetic perception of everyday objects reflects the aesthetic appreciation facet.

items.text: I enjoy learning about topics that have no practical application, just for the sake of knowing.
items.rationale: Intellectual curiosity without utilitarian motivation is a hallmark of the inquisitiveness facet.

items.text: I often come up with creative solutions that others wouldn't have thought of.
items.rationale: Novel problem-solving and divergent thinking reflect the creativity facet.

items.text: I would describe my taste in music, art, and film as eclectic and wide-ranging.
items.rationale: Broad and varied aesthetic preferences are a behavioral marker of aesthetic appreciation and unconventionality.

items.text: I find it fascinating to consider how people in other cultures see the world differently.
items.rationale: Interest in diverse cultural perspectives reflects intellectual curiosity and unconventionality.

items.text: I often question established rules and traditions, wondering if there's a better way.
items.rationale: Questioning conventions and seeking alternatives reflects the unconventionality facet.

items.text: I can spend hours absorbed in a book about a subject I've never encountered before.
items.rationale: Deep absorption in novel intellectual material reflects the inquisitiveness facet.

items.text: I enjoy visiting art galleries and museums and can lose track of time there.
items.rationale: Behavioral engagement with aesthetic environments is a direct indicator of aesthetic appreciation.

items.text: I sometimes have ideas that feel ahead of their time, and I wish others could see what I see.
items.rationale: Visionary thinking reflects creativity and unconventionality, but the wish for recognition could touch on Extraversion (social self-esteem) or low Honesty-Humility (grandiosity).

items.text: I get restless doing the same routine every day and crave new experiences.
items.rationale: Novelty-seeking maps to Openness, but restlessness with routine could also reflect low Conscientiousness (difficulty with structure).

items.text: I like to keep my options open and explore different possibilities rather than commit to one plan.
items.rationale: Preference for flexibility could reflect Openness (exploration, unconventionality) or low Conscientiousness (lack of planning and commitment).
